Determine the velocity of the particle as it exits hole b.

The particle starts at rest at hole a and accelerates due to the electric potential difference U between plates M and N, giving the particle kinetic energy equal to the work done by the electric field: (1/2)mv^2 = qU.
Solve for the velocity: v = sqrt(2qU/m).
This is the velocity with which the particle enters region I (the magnetic field).
In region I, the particle encounters a uniform magnetic field B pointing in the positive x-direction. The velocity v is along the z-direction.
The magnetic force on the particle is: F = qv x B, which is in the negative y-direction, creating a circular motion in the y-z plane.
For circular motion in a magnetic field: F = qvB = mv^2/R, therefore R = mv/(qB).
Substitute the expression for v: R = m(sqrt(2qU/m))/(qB) = sqrt(2mqU)/(qB) = sqrt(2mU)/(Bsqrt(q)).
Verification that the radius R is determined solely by the mass of the particle (m), the charge of the particle (q), the potential difference (U), and the magnetic field strength (B).
The values of d and E (the electric field in region II) don't affect the radius of the circular path in region I, aligning with physics principles.
The radius of the circular path of the particle in the magnetic field is R = mv/(qB) = sqrt(2mU)/(Bsqrt(q)).
